citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The peafowl have access to the top part of the outdoor two-enclosure aviary structure, where they roost on the roof and
defecate. Excessive accumulation of excreta was present on the wire mesh roof of the aviary, where directly below the
accumulations, birds such as ducks, chickens and guineafowl were resting or using aquatic areas. The facility
representative indicated this part of the primary enclosure needed to be cleaned. Failure to remove excreta from the top
of the aviary as often as necessary may cause birds housed within to become soiled or exposed to disease hazards from
particulates that fall through the wire mesh roof (approximately 0.5-inch square openings). Excreta and food waste must
be removed from primary enclosures and from under and around primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent
excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent the soiling of the birds contained in the primary enclosures,
and to reduce disease hazards.
Correct by 15 November 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The peafowl have access to the top part of the outdoor two-enclosure aviary structure, where they roost on the roof and 
defecate. Excessive accumulation of excreta was present on the wire mesh roof of the aviary, where directly below the 
accumulations, birds such as ducks, chickens and guineafowl were resting or using aquatic areas. The facility 
representative indicated this part of the primary enclosure needed to be cleaned. Failure to remove excreta from the top 
of the aviary as often as necessary may cause birds housed within to become soiled or exposed to disease hazards from 
particulates that fall through the wire mesh roof (approximately 0.5-inch square openings). Excreta and food waste must 
be removed from primary enclosures and from under and around primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent 
excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent the soiling of the birds contained in the primary enclosures, 
and to reduce disease hazards.  
 
Correct by 15 November 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
